thread.title: MPs’ rebuke for playing Sherlock falls on Watson’s deaf ears
thread.title_full: MPs’ rebuke for playing Sherlock falls on Watson’s deaf ears

title: MPs’ rebuke for playing Sherlock falls on Watson’s deaf ears
text:
Welcome to your preview of The Times Subscribe now MPs’ rebuke for playing Sherlock falls on Watson’s deaf ears Tom Watson, right, was sincere but not wholly convincing when he apologised PA Patrick Kidd Political Sketch Published 1 minute ago 
Billy Bunter perched on the edge of his chair and gazed owlishly through his spectacles at the home affairs select committee. Beasts and fatheads, the lot of them, but Bunter knew what he had to do. “I’m s-sincerely sorry,” he said. Bob Monkhouse once said that the key to success in show business was sincerity: “Once you can fake that, you’ve got it made.” Ditto for politics. Perhaps the Bunteresque Tom Watson was sincere when he apologised to the family of Leon Brittan for smearing his name, but it was not wholly convincing. 
“I’m very sorry for the distress caused,” Subscribe now
